utterances: Of course, some of her patients did choose to leave.
Some just didn't want to pay the new fee.
Others found they were forced to leave because their insurance companies won't allow Dr. Crowley to order tests or refer patients to specialists.
That was the case for Kim Nardy(ph).
Yeah, I do wish she was still was accepting insurance because I would have stayed as a patient, but I respect her decision to not do that anymore.
Even though she is no longer a patient here, Nardy stopped in just to chat and to drop off a Christmas present for Dr. Crowley.
Serenity tea leaf(ph) holder, and it's really pretty.
For me, there was also this feeling of guilt to make a decision where you know you have to almost do something mean to people is hard.
But Crowley doesn't regret that decision.
She says the alternative might have been no practice at all.
For NPR News, I'm Joel Rose in Cape May, New Jersey.
(Soundbite of music)
There are some pictures of Dr. ""Boots"" Crowley and the letter from her sister that inspired the story at our blog, npr.org/daydreaming.
(Soundbite of music)
There's more coming up on Day to Day from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is Day to Day.
The investment bank, Lehman Brothers, could be sold as soon as this weekend.
Bank executives are said to be working furiously to find a buyer.
Marketplace's Nancy Marshall-Genzer is here now.
And Nancy, why the rush?
Well, Madeleine, some reports say the federal government wants a final deal by this weekend before markets in Asia open for Monday trading.
I called Lehman Brothers to ask them about this, but they wouldn't comment.
They're really not talking to the press at this point.
But Lehman does have a reason to try to move this deal along as quickly as it can.
Lehman borrows money daily - that's how it operates - but for now, it has had to pay higher interest rates because of people's perception that it's in trouble.
And perceptions are very important.
I talked about this with bank analyst Scott Sprinzen at Standard & Poor's, and he says Lehman is especially vulnerable to market psychology.
They are highly leveraged financial institutions, which are very beholden to the market for their day-to-day funding requirements, which makes them subject to the swings in market psychology.
And Sprinzen says Lehman's underlying business is strong, and a sale of the company is being driven largely by that market psychology.
All right, Nancy, let's talk about consumers now.
Do Lehman's troubles affect average consumers, maybe average consumers who don't think that they have a stake in a big investment bank?
Yeah, like you and me, Madeleine.
Right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't have a big stake in Lehman's.
But you and I are affected, along with lots of other consumers.
Banks are hunkering down.
They're trying to build up stockpiles of cash not just for a rainy day, but for a rainy year, it seems.
They need a lot of money themselves, and they just don't want to make loans right now.
Richard Bove is another bank analyst.
He's with Ladenburg Thalmann.
He told me that we're going to pay higher interest rates for all kinds of loans.
Mortgage rates are going to go up.
The rates on an auto loan are going to go up.
The rates on a credit-card loan are going to go up.
All these rates are going to go up because banks are reluctant to lend.
Now, Madeleine, another thing consumers worry about is whether their tax money will be used to help Lehman, and the government is trying to avoid that.
A bailout, in other words?
Exactly.
Who is in the position then to buy Lehman and avoid that bailout?
Bank of America is emerging as the most likely buyer, and Richard Bove says it would be a natural fit.
And he says Bank of America could easily swallow Lehman's losses in the sub-prime mortgage area.
And is it - does it look likely that that sale will go through, or will it end up being us, the taxpayers?
Well, at this point, it really doesn't look like we're going to be bailing out Lehman, we taxpayers.
And the Fed is - and the government as a whole, is just trying to avoid that.
It just doesn't want to be seen as an endless source of cash for expensive bailouts.
Thanks, Nancy.
That's Nancy Marshall-Genzer of public radio's daily business show Marketplace.
(Soundbite of music)
Summary Judgment when NPR's Day to Day continues.
I'm Farai Chideya, and this is News & Notes.

Holly Robinson Peete has been in the spotlight since she was a preschooler on ""Sesame Street."" She went on to star in the '80s hit series ""21 Jump Street."" She shared the screen with Johnny Depp and with Steven Williams, who played Captain Adam Fuller.
(Soundbite from ""21 Jump Street"")
(As Officer Judy Hoffs) So?
So tell me about him.
How does he look up close?
Nobody really has cheekbones like that.
I believe Jeremy Woods is totally fine.
He's hot.
I'd let the guy eat crackers in my bed.
Why didn't I get this assignment?
(As Captain Adam Fuller) That is why.
Peete also starred in the sitcom ""Hangin' With Mister Cooper"" and played Diana Ross on a TV mini-series.
Today, she hosts a radio show and heads a foundation for Parkinson's disease awareness.
Peete still won't slow down.
She's just written a foreword to ""Book of Life,"" a collection of contemporary words of wisdom from mothers like herself.
She and I spoke earlier about how she faces some of her life challenges, including her son's autism.
The most key factor to making your best days happen is to breathe, is to just take in the moment.
Any time we hit a challenge, or if I'm feeling tremendously stressed, I'll do a spa day, or I'll take a yoga class or I'll just do something that focuses on myself.
And the ""Book of Life: Making Your Best Days Happen,"" I wrote in that book I wrote a foreword, talking about our challenges with autism and how that brought us together as a family.
You know, it's no secret that the divorce rate with autism is about at 80 percent.
So when we got that diagnosis in 1999, we came across a lot of challenges.
So we managed to take a bad thing, a thing that really felt like it could potentially tear us apart as a couple and as a family, and we turned it into something positive.
The four kids are like, why can't we be on?
And you know, so, I promised them once a month they get a little appearance, so they've been doing their prep work for that.
Oh, that's fabulous.
That's what's so incredible about these countries.
And the sanctions are difficult for them, but yet they have been able to survive.
And they believe so strongly in a united Europe and so strongly in NATO, that's their protection.
They are too small of a country to go it alone, and they get that.
They are concerned, yes, about some of the statements that have been made like Newt Gingrich saying that Estonia was nothing more than a suburb of St. Petersburg.
Yeah, that concerned them.
At the same time, they know that Congress has stood with them, that there's bipartisan support, and that's why we came together.
They also believe Senator McCain when he has said that he has directly spoken to the president-elect, and that he has said that he will continue to support NATO.

So our mission here is to stand tall with these countries, to answer their questions about what was a very volatile election in the U.S., and to tell them that we will have a smooth transition of power, and that there is strong bipartisan support in the Congress for going after the cyberattacks and for standing true to their independence.
Is there a chance that this just exacerbates an already fraught relationship between two nuclear powers?
You know, we have two choices here.

We can just pretend this didn't happen to us, when the best intelligence agencies of the world has is telling us that it has happened, or we can decide to make the world know that we are willing to stand up against this kind of attack.
This is the new-fangled way to undermine a country's democracy, and potentially look at how you undermine their economic system.
And if we let this happen to us, it's going to start happening to other countries.

And as you sit here on the frontline of these Baltic states like we are today, for us to just pretend it's not happening would be not just an insult to them, but really an insult to democracies the world over.
And that's why I think it's so important that the president has taken these actions.
Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat from Minnesota, thank you so much.
All right, thank you.
Baseball commissioner Bud Selig has issued two major decisions.
First, that Major League Baseball will not celebrate Barry Bonds' 715th homerun.
Selig explained that the record is Hank Aaron's 755, and that there's no reason to mark second place, even when that means passing the hallowed total amassed by Babe Ruth.
There's widespread suspicion that Selig is reluctant to honor a man just as widely suspected of illegal steroid use, and reportedly, the subject of a federal perjury investigation.
Then, yesterday, Selig announced the sale of the Washington Nationals, one of the worst teams in the game, for $450 million.
If you have questions about either of these decisions, our number is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
Our baseball pal Alan Schwarz joins us now from his home in New York.
He's a senior writer for Baseball America.
